Mr. Bungle was just another alternative band that major labels had sent on tour in hopes of becoming the next big thing from the musical underworld. To me, it was a chance to come face-to-face with alternative life-forms.

As my friends and I smoked outside, people of all ages surrounded us, waiting to get through security: older metalheads with thick wavy hair; young scruffians wearing oversized flannels and baggy jeans; stoners in leather jackets with stringy shoulder-length hair. And lots of young kids wearing Mr. Bungle’s infamous “There’s a Tractor in My Balls” t-shirts. After the show, I bought a bootleg Bungle shirt from a guy selling shirts in the parking lot outside the club. Wearing band shirts to the band’s show was not cool. Anyway, I rarely wore band shirts. I never owned a Soundgarden or Nirvana shirt, but with Bungle, I wore that shirt everywhere. I wanted to provoke people and set myself apart. This band was a taunt and a wall I built between us and the conventional, safe world. It was my way of saying I’d set sail for my own weird paradise, and you couldn’t come.

Without the tape recorder, I felt relaxed when we reached security. For once we had no contraband to make us worry. By this time tomorrow I imagined how I will have made copies of this concert recording for all my friends, and I’d be stoked for the rest of my Bungle-loving life. First, I needed to find Ted.

My friends and I searched all corners of the venue, walking through the mosh pit area multiple times and checking the far back room where there were, I think, pool tables and wobbly black tables where people who didn’t mosh would sit during shows. I never sat during shows. I stood front and center by the stage and moshed off and on. When we needed a break from moshing at this club, we liked to perch ourselves on a high area above the pit where we could see the band without any obstruction. We stood there and scanned the club for Ted. He was nowhere to be found. That made me nervous.

The club’s layout made it one of my favorite places to see shows. It was basically a semicircle. The stage stood in the center. The main floor was street level and put you basically at eye-level with the stage. A second narrow, elevated tier ran below the main floor—like a carpeted boardwalk—so you could see over the audience’s head and always see the band, and carpeted stairs ran along the right of the stage. A big disco ball hung overhead. It was there at every show, though I never saw it spin.

A glass divider split the venue in half, separating the all-ages side from the over-21 folks by the bar. The soundboard stood in the center, at the end of the divider, right where I dreamed of handing the engineer a tape and saying, “I’ll pay you to record this.” The pit was below the board, with plenty of room to mosh.

I peered through the glass divider but didn’t see Ted there either. Maybe he was one of those people who skipped opening bands. Then I worried: What if he got there after Bungle’s set started and I couldn’t record the first songs? What if I didn’t see him come in in the dark? I didn’t want to spend my time scanning the club instead watching the band. Fucking Ted, you stoner! Why didn’t we make a concrete plan to meet at a certain place at a certain time? Instead, I’d agreed to his loose-goosey We’ll, like, find each other, man plan and look where it got me. Admittedly, I was a stoned idiot, too.

My friends and I abandoned that and positioned ourselves along the back wall of the pit and waited. A heavy San Francisco band named Grotus opened. I didn’t know anything about Grotus other than their name was a fun to say. Apparently, Mike Patton had seen the band play in San Francisco and asked them to tour with Bungle. All I remember about them is my anticipation waiting for Bungle.

At some point some dude walked by me in the crowd wearing the kind of blue mechanics jumpsuit that zipped up the chest. After a painfully long time after Grotus, the houselights went dark and the crowd erupted in applause. When Bungle took the stage, the singer was wearing the same jumpsuit, except he had a black leather bondage mask over his face. It was Patton.

The guitarist was wearing a jumpsuit, too. Patton undid the zipper over his mouth so he could press his lips to the microphone, but first his tongue slipped out from the hole, like a pink sea slug emerging from its shell. I don’t remember anything he said, only the horror of the gesture, and the effect of not seeing his face. It’s creepy when you can read peoples’ expressions. It’s even creepier when you can’t see their eyes.

Everyone took their positions.

Spruance stationed himself on the right side of the stage, hunched, his feet set wide apart in a battle stance, as he gripped his guitar. He wore a clear mask whose expression never changed, no matter how hard he banged his head or how high he jumped. Dreadlocks spilled from the back of his emotionless mask like wires from the mixing board.

Dunn wore shorts and a Hellraiser mask whose rubber nails wiggled when he played, and he looked down at us from the stage, like we were scum.

Two horn players positioned themselves in the back right corner beside the drum set and behind Trey Spruance. One wore a clear mask, the other some kind of monster mask.

The drummer just stared straight ahead like a robot then started playing a sweet instrumental introduction that Patton sang gently over. It was The Alan Parsons Project’s “Time.” After a long tense break, a creepy organ started to play, and they played an unsettling instrumental cover of Henry Mancini’s “The Thing Strikes.” Then Patton squatted down low and shifted side to side, like a silverback gorilla ready to pounce, and the band broke into “Travolta.”

The huge sound rattled the soles of our feet. You could feel the sinister organ in your chest, and my ears immediately hurt. The audience screamed and swirled into a mosh pit that sucked us all in as guitar riffs and Patton’s screams filled the club. As one of the horn players pumped the organ, Patton started flailing, gripping the mic in both hands, and bouncing up and down, until he whipped his hands in a circle that took the mic over his head, spinning his body around toward the drum set and banging his head, flipping the microphone chord with him.

Patton chirped into the mic at the end of “Travolta,” drawing air from deep in the back of his throat, creating an eerie cascade of high-pitched sounds like a flock of dying seagulls. He was perfecting the vocal affects he would use for years in all his other bands.

Song after song, Patton had the terrifying unpredictability of someone unhinged. Everything about Bungle in 1992 was designed to scare you.

When you’re a young rock and roller, you want your music loud, weird, shocking, and scary. To me, these band members were emissaries from a darker world. They’d descended on my city to perform their carnival show before their spaceship whisked them away. They seemed so inhuman that they’d likely just crawled out of a hole in the earth and climbed onto the stage. What my teen self couldn’t see was that they were just a bunch of guys on a long North American tour, fresh out of high school, with adolescent senses of humor. Instead of crawling back into the hole after the show, they’d climb into a sweaty rented Econoline-type van parked in the back of the club, filled with hamburger wrappers and earplugs. I didn’t see bands that way yet. How could I? Bands weren’t like me. Even if you knew the power chords on “Travolta,” normal people sure as hell couldn’t write music like that. That’s why they were on stage and we were down in the pit: to witness something abnormal before you returned to your earthly life.

They played nearly the whole album, one favorite song after another.

The band sounded great, because no matter how many overdubs and samples they had on the album, underneath it all and their theater, their songs are well constructed and the musicians talented as hell.

The stage at After the Gold Rush was the usual long rectangle, but in the center it came to a point, creating a little triangular pier that pushed into the audience. Patton would station himself there over the mosh pit, while we stood staring up at him. There were no huge speakers to perch himself on. Instead, he prowled the stage, like a tiger with devious energy to burn. During slower moments, Patton paced around snapping his fingers like a jazz crooner, creating a creepy pastiche of a psycho killer who likes to swing dance. Once, he took a sip of something set on the drum stand, then with one quick convulsion, he let the cup fly into the air, spraying himself.

The horn players were like a second stage of their own. During certain songs, one would prowl the corner of the stage, pacing like an animal, while the other would play keyboard. Other times they’d both grab their horns and blow a few lines before acting like they were fist-fighting or rolling around on the ground.

One left the stage during a song, then rushed back out, held a lighter to his lips, and spit lighter fluid, sending a huge fireball over the audience’s heads. No one expected that.

During another song, one horn player ran out and dumped a big plastic trough of water on us. It missed me but soaked my feet. After that, the pit was dangerous. Not only did people push and throw elbows, they slipped on the wet concrete. The horn players managed to dance on their wet stage.

Spruance hunched over his guitar, shredding. Sometimes when he jumped, he kept his standing position and simply lifted his feet off the stage as if by levitation. When he banged his head, his dreads flung back and forth over the top of it, whipping around.

During one song, Patton swung the microphone in a circle at his side, helicoptering it on the chord in quick dangerous revolutions, then tightening the circle so the mic popped back into his hand when it was time to sing.

At another point he shoved the mic through the zipper whole in his mask and held it in his mouth. He’d lock his hands together and whip them through the air like he was trying to pull invisible shackles from the wall. He’d dance and nearly loose his footing on the wooden stage floor. Behind him the horn players did the cabbage patch.

After one song Patton crouched low, tightened the microphone chord around the back of his elbow and around his wrist, the way you wrap the vacuum cleaner chord around the two pegs, and he growled “Spit on me” into the microphone. People did.

Beer bottles flew from the 21 and over side. Cups half full of beer landed on stage, exploding on impact. When the spit flew, wad after wad came from all directions. In the silence between songs you could hear people hocking throatfuls of lung-butter and launching it toward the stage. My friends and I stood right beneath Patton’s feet, so spit ricocheted off us. We didn’t care. Above us, Patton stood perfectly still as the spit covered him. One huge spitball landed right on the tip of his nose, and it dangled there, slowly elongating as gravity pulled at it and the phlegm held it in place. My friend JR and I looked at each other in horror. It was repellant. It is still one of the more theatrical things I’ve seen on stage. These musicians owned their stage personas, taking every vile thing that went along with it. To me it seemed brave. I wanted to cultivate that sort of commitment to something—anything—in my own life.

He was the most captivating singers I’d seen at that age. To this day, he remains one of the most charismatic.

The concert felt evil yet playful. There was so much destructive theater.

At one point, Patton reached down at his feet and pulled a board from the top of the stage, then he tossed it into the audience where we passed it over our heads for a while, passed it back on stage, and someone put it back in place.

There was also a sense of group catharsis in the audience. People jumped and moshed and flung themselves around. They needed to blow off steam. This band was so unhinged up there that their personas felt like invitations to lose our minds, too. There was a sense that anything could happen here.

The 1990s were the era of stagediving. People loved to get up there to fling themselves back into the crowd and have their MTV moment, floating onto of the audience’s hands. People eyeballed the stage here, but it stood too high for most people to bother climbing it. Our friend Nate did, though, and he got kicked out during the third song. Security grabbed him and hustled him right out the front door, where he hung outside for the next hour. Dumb move. This wasn’t a Pearl Jam video.

When another guy jumped on stage, two heavy men wearing only thong underwear rushed from the wings, pinned the stage diver down, and dry humped him. One guy held the kid’s shoulders, while the other pried open his legs and climbed on top to pump his groin against him for a few rounds. Then the men rolled the dude off the stage like a sack of flour. Young hetero men are so sexually insecure. Getting publicly fucked by a naked man in public was a genius deterrent. I only saw two other people stagedive after that. One got away. The other got fucked by the naked men. No one tried after that.

Ted never showed, and I was pissed. As we stumbled out of the club back into the chilly night, the sense that I was a cool connected insider faded. Instead, I felt cool from having witnessed this. I also thought: Fucking hippie!

We found Nate waiting outside. He tried to play it cool, acting like his stagedive was so epic that he didn’t mind missing half the show, but we’d all seen his dive. We just shook our heads and said, “You missed out.”

When my friends asked what I was going to do about my recording equipment, I shrugged. I don’t really care, I probably said, I’ll get it whenever. Like Nate, I hid my disappointment.

On the drive home we marveled at what we’d just experienced and relived our favorite moments. We’d be doing that the rest of our lives.

When I went back to the headshop a few days later to fetch my poster and equipment, I hoped Ted wasn’t there. But there he was, presiding over the drug paraphernalia whose true names we dare not speak.

Hey, I muttered. Came for my stuff.

He tucked his long hair behind his ear as he fetched it and the large concert poster from beneath the counter. He apologized and explained: He didn’t meet because the band ended up recording the show themselves through the soundboard, so I wouldn’t have wanted to record the show on my crappy cassette deck anyway, which is true. They’d promised him a copy, but they were too dissatisfied with their performance to share the recording. “I didn’t even get a copy,” Ted said.

Dissatisfied? That was the greatest show I’d seen in my life! What about it disappointed them?

I’m sure the fidelity sounded great, Ted said, but they didn’t think they played as well as they can, so they kept the recording.

Wow, I said, but I didn’t know whether to believe him. I want to, but he still hadn’t given me a copy of that Club Lingerie footage he’d promised. What if Bungle had given him a copy of this After the Goldrush show and he just wasn’t sharing it with me? Dick move, but I’d never know. I was young enough that I still deluded myself into thinking that I could rely on stoners. Instead of returning home with a private soundboard recording of prime Bungle and my crappy audience recording, I had no copies. Before the internet, you had to work hard to find good bootleg recordings. I wouldn’t see any early live Bungle recordings surface for years.

When my crew went to the headshop after that, I avoided Ted. I stayed angry for a little while. With time, I became grateful: If I had recorded the show, I would have had a totally different experience. Instead of being upfront getting water sprayed on my head and my hair singed by flames, staring up into Mike Patton’s nostrils through that leather mask, I would’ve spent the whole show standing somewhere in the shadows, trying to position the tape recorder to get the best sound while trying not to get caught. That would’ve sucked. I’m glad Ted didn’t meet me. He freed me to experience one of the greatest shows of my life. And it turns out that someone else taped the show that night, and the cassette recording eventually surfaced on the internet. It sounds tinny and flat, but it’s still good enough to help me relive the magic and check my memories against.

I still do wonder if Bungle did record the show through the soundboard? If they did, maybe there’s some way I can get a copy? I messaged bassist Trevor Dunn but didn’t hear back.

Fans recorded many of the shows from the audience on that tour, and recordings of various quality from Denver, Chicago, Boston, Cleveland, Florida, DC, New York, and New Jersey have surfaced. Even though Ted flaked on sharing that 1991 Club Lingerie concert footage, too, decades later I found the footage on YouTube. It’s not as good as what we saw the following year.

Stroke me, stroke me.

Stroke!

One commenter summed up my experience exactly: “Was at that show—the ‘spit on me’ moment is one of the most bizarre concert experiences I ever had.”

Thirty years later, that’s still true.

The internet surfaced other killer recordings, including two soundboard recordings from 1991: one in Oakland, and one in Berkeley.

After that tour, the band members played tons of shows in their other bands around California, between Bungle tours. Dunn’s bands played many gigs at restaurants and weddings and restaurants.

When I graduated from high school in 1993, I started college down the street from the club where Bungle played, and a few years passed without any more local Bungle shows. I assumed they were writing their second album. I kept listening to my old one until the CD’s silver surface got scratched and dull. Then in October 1995, they released it, Disco Volante. It had none of the macabre clown porn vibes. On first listen, my friends and I were disappointed.

Disco Volante wasn’t as overtly creepy as Mr. Bungle, but somehow it was still very creepy and often less listenable than the first album. Disco Volante may actually be weirder. It’s equally inventive and also—dare I say it—mature.

“It’s definitely the ‘coming of age’ album,” Spruance told one interviewer. “I’m happy with it. Disco Volante sort of sublimated or re-purposed our mania of 91/92 towards things like record production, i.e. getting the sound, whatever it takes — not just being content to have all the parts represented. We weren’t worrying about it sounding like a ‘band,’ as much as worrying later on about how to arrange the music for a live performance as a band. That was a healthy challenge to ourselves as much as to anyone else. But in ’95 if you wanted to do anything ambitious you’d really have to smash through the ’80s/90s crust that had been obscuring the whole music world's approach to ‘the studio’— I think we did it.”

At first, I was sad that they’d moved out of what clearly now resembled their clown phase in hindsight. I liked the new music they made, but I thought I preferred to feel disturbed more than challenged. But like the band, I was older now, in college not high school. I was listening to jazz and surf instrumental music at the time, and my new musical tastes opened me up to Disco Volante. As I kept listening, the album grew on me. I’d also read enough Rolling Stone magazine by then to know that these dudes weren’t emissaries from another planet, they were working musicians with rent to pay and parents who missed them between holidays and siblings who made fun of them for being freaks, and as artists, they were always evolving. They’d ditched death metal for funk and ska before. Now they were ditching the evil circus for more avant-garde world music. They’d purged their Northern rural California experience on Mr. Bungle. Now they were exploring new musical horizons.

Not all fans could let it go.
